newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Bonos ended lower after a seesaw trading day. They started lower, depressed by a weaker dollar, then bounced back on positive news about Italy's mini-budget, and fell back again pulled by falling U.S. Treasuries.
"What's true is the market is very nervous and we have not decided yet where the direction has to be," a dealer said.
Spain's market was closely watching the peseta, after Bank of Spain intervention today and yesterday.
The Spanish unit was a little stronger at the close around 84.79/81 per mark, given the U.S. dollar recovery in late European trade.

Dealers said the 10-year spread over the Bund should stay below 135 basis points in the short run. It was trading around 124 basis points at the close today after having touched 130 basis points yesterday.
